â€œWhat do you mean? Understandâ€¦ what?â€ Zametov asked, clearly confused. 

Raskolnikovâ€™s serious face shifted dramatically. He burst into that same nervous laugh again, like he couldnâ€™t help himself. In a flash, he vividly recalled a recent moment: standing with an axe behind the door, while the latch shook and the guys outside swore and rattled it. He felt a wild urge to shout at them, to curse, to stick out his tongue, to mock them, and just laugh and laugh! ğŸ˜‚

â€œYouâ€™re either crazy, orâ€¦â€ Zametov started, then paused, as if struck by a sudden thought. 

â€œOr? Or what? Spill it!â€ 

â€œNothing,â€ Zametov snapped, getting annoyed. â€œItâ€™s all nonsense!â€ 

They fell silent. After that burst of laughter, Raskolnikov turned serious and gloomy. He rested his elbow on the table and leaned his head on his hand, completely zoning out on Zametov. The silence stretched on. 

â€œWhy arenâ€™t you drinking your tea? Itâ€™s getting cold,â€ Zametov said. 

â€œWhat? Tea? Oh, rightâ€¦â€ Raskolnikov took a sip, popped a piece of bread in his mouth, and suddenly looked at Zametov as if remembering everything. He pulled himself together, and his face shifted back to its original expression.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov experiences a moment of intense reflection and emotional turmoil, recalling a past moment of tension while conversing with Zametov.
